awd_titl_txt: CIBR: Collaborative Research: CIBR Expanding structure coverage of genomes to facilitate macromolecular assembly determination.
awd_abstract_narration:
The Protein Data Bank (PDB) is the single global archive of three-dimensional (3D) structures of large biological molecules. Despite a steady increase in its holdings, the growth of the PDB is far outstripped by the growth in the available protein sequence data. Resources like Genome3D (genome3d.eu), funded by the BBSRC, aim to fill the gap in structure coverage of the protein sequence space with reliable predictions of structures. These approaches largely model proteins that are closely related to a protein of known structure. The Rosetta method for predicting protein structures, a world-leading approach developed by the Baker lab in the USA, was recently enhanced with information derived from evolutionary analyses of protein sequence data, yielding reliable models even for cases where sequence identity between the model and the available experimental structures is very low. This project will integrate Rosetta models into Genome3D to expand the coverage of structural data for important organisms for health and food security. It will also enrich both the experimentally determined and computationally predicted structures with valuable functional annotations, such as information pertaining to surface interfaces, a key ingredient in understanding how proteins interact with each other and with other biological molecules. By focusing on proteins dissimilar to those with known structures, this portal will help fill the gaps in structure coverage of the protein sequence space and will make structure data much more readily available and accessible. Finally, novel visualization tools integrating the presentation of the predicted and experimentally determined structures will be developed, maintaining a clear distinction between what is predicted and what is experimentally determined. 

The expanded set of 3D models derived from this project will in turn help to expand the coverage of sequence space even further, since these models can be used to guide the experimental determination of protein structures being obtained by powerful new structural biology techniques like cryo-Electron Microscopy (EM). This project will also endeavor, where possible, to improve the assembly of individual protein structures into macromolecular complexes which can be analyzed to determine their biological role. Scientists in both academia and industrial sectors will benefit from access to such an integrated portal, assisting them in designing new medicines, understanding the mechanism of disease, or in designing proteins with novel properties. Recent advances in Electron Microscopy allows near routine determination of structures of large molecular machines and is in need of a large repertoire of "building blocks" in interpreting the experimental results, a need which will be partially addressed by the new portal and its provision of expanded domain structure libraries. The portal will also have ways to access the assembled data programmatically, benefiting power users: software developers and maintainers of other resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through the funding of NSF in the last three years, we have been able to push the boundaries of macromolecular structure modeling to the new level through the use of deep learning methods. Prior to the award state-of-the-art protein structure prediction methods either relied heavily on homologs with known structure in the Protein Data Bank (PDB) or used co-evolutionary information extracted from vast sets of homologous protein sequences collected over databases such as UniProt, JGI's IMG/M or MGnify. Application of deep learning-based methods however revealed the possibility of generating atom-level accuracy models of proteins and protein complexes even in data-scarce scenarios with very limited information on homologous sequences and structures available.

The two structure prediction networks, trRosetta (Yang et al., 2020; Anishchenko et al., 2021; Baek et al., 2021) and RoseTTAFold (Baek et al., 2021), developed within the scope of this NSF award should be of broad utility for researchers working in the field of structural biology. The networks enable the rapid solution of challenging X-ray crystallography and cryo-EM structure modeling problems, and thus provide insights into the functions of proteins of currently unknown structure. Real world use examples include solving an X-ray structure of the human Rubicon-Rab7 complex at 2.8 angstrom resolution (Bhargava et al. 2020) with the help of trRosetta, as well as solving atomic-level structure of the 1mDa Fanconi Anemia core complex (FAcc) from cryoEM data at 4.6 angstrom resolution (Farrell et al., 2020). RoseTTAFold enabled experimental structure determination of four proteins, which had eluded solution by molecular replacement (MR) using models available in the PDB, by providing accurate structure models for MR (Baek et al., 2021). We also showed that structure models of proteins associated with human diseases generated by RoseTTAFold help in gaining better understanding of how these mutations affect protein function (Baek et al., 2021; Sen et al., 2022).

Not only the newly developed tools facilitate structure determination of proteins and protein-protein complexes which are known to interact, but they also make it possible to systematically screen through interactions on the entire proteome level to identify new interactions with performance comparable to that of large-scale experimental methods (Humphreys I et al., 2021). As the result of evaluating interactions between 8.3 million pairs of yeast proteins, we identified 1505 which are likely to interact, and built structure models for 106 previously unidentified assemblies and 806 that have not been structurally characterized. These complexes, which have as many as five subunits, play roles in almost all key processes in eukaryotic cells and provide broad insights into biological function.

All the above progress in protein structure prediction has already had immense positive influence on de novo protein design as well (Anishchenko et al., 2021; Norn et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2022). We have shown that a deep neural network trained exclusively on native sequences and structures can generalize to create completely new proteins that fold into stable structures (Anishchenko et al., 2021). Unlike traditional protein design calculations, in which properties of the target scaffold such as the overall topology and/or the secondary structure element lengths and locations are specified in advance, through a structure 'blueprint' or other approach, the ability of the network to generate plausible protein structures from scratch makes the de novo protein design process much more streamlined. It allows researchers to directly focus on the functional parts of the designed protein and let the network figure out the rest of the structure for them (Wang et al., 2022). 

We believe these last three years have been highly fruitful in terms of accomplishments in pushing forward the boundaries of what is possible in macromolecular modeling and de novo protein design. We plan to continue our current trajectory and continue to improve upon our technologies so that designed proteins can tackle next-generation problems that the world faces today. 

References

 

  1. 10.1073/pnas.1914677117

  2. 10.1002/prot.26194

  3. 10.1002/prot.26197

  4. 10.1126/science.abj8754

  5. 10.1073/pnas.2008030117.

  6. 10.1101/2020.05.01.072751

  7. 10.1126/science.abm4805

  8. 10.1038/s41586-021-04184-w

  9. 10.1073/pnas.2017228118

  10.  10.1126/science.abn2100

 

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2022
Modified by: David Baker
